title: Points
text:
Challenge Classic: Map with point data (e.g., individual locations, points of interest, clusters). Focus on effective symbolization and density visualization.
For this one, we will be looking at the List of Largest LGBT Events on Wikipedia and map them by size.




In order to get the data from Wikipedia to our R, we will use the rvest package


Code
library(pacman)
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, ragg, rvest, rnaturalearth, showtext, 
              janitor, sf, tidygeocoder, ggrepel, scales)

events_raw <- read_html("https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_largest_LGBT_events") |> 
  html_table() |> 
  purrr::pluck(4) |>  
  janitor::clean_names()

world <- ne_countries(scale = "medium", returnclass = "sf")






Now that we have the raw table, it is necessary to clean and transform the data.


Code
events <- events_raw |> 
  mutate(
    rank = str_remove(rank, " \\(tie\\)"), # remove the "tie" events 
    # transform strings into numbers
    organizers_statistics = str_remove(organizers_statistics, "\\+*\\[.+"),
    organizers_statistics = parse_number(organizers_statistics),
    authorities_statistics = str_remove(authorities_statistics, "\\+*\\[.+"),
    authorities_statistics = parse_number(authorities_statistics),
    # creates a new column for attendence with organizer_statistics, or authorities if necessary
    attendance = if_else(!is.na(organizers_statistics), organizers_statistics, authorities_statistics)
  ) |> 
    # select the most recent event per city
  group_by(city) |> 
  slice_max(order_by = year, n = 1) |> 
  ungroup()

head(events)


# A tibble: 6 × 8
  rank  city    support  year organizers_statistics authorities_statistics type 
  <chr> <chr>   <chr>   <int>                 <dbl>                  <dbl> <chr>
1 36    Amster… Local    2014                560000                 450000 Para…
2 47    Atlanta Local    2018                300000                     NA Para…
3 58    Belo H… Local    2019                200000                 200000 Para…
4 46    Berlin  Local    2022                    NA                 350000 Para…
5 34    Boston  Local    2019                750000                     NA Para…
6 42    Bright… Local    2018                450000                 450000 Para…
# ℹ 1 more variable: attendance <dbl>


In order to correctly place the points in our map, we will need the coordinates for the cities present in the dataset. The tidygeocoder package will get this info for us automatically (a huge help! I used to depend on Google and AI to do this…)


Code
events_geo <- events |> 
  slice_max(order_by = attendance, n = 10) |> # keep only the top 20 to avoid convolution 
  distinct(city, .keep_all = TRUE) |> 
  geocode(city = city, method = "osm")

# Convert to sf object 
events_geo_sf <- st_as_sf(events_geo, coords = c("long", "lat"), crs = 4326)
events_geo_sf <- events_geo_sf |>
  arrange(desc(attendance)) |>
  mutate(
    city_color = factor(city, levels = city)
  )

# Transform to Natural Earth projection
natearth_crs <- "+proj=natearth +lon_0=0 +datum=WGS84"
world_transformed <- st_transform(world, crs = natearth_crs)
events_transformed <- st_transform(events_geo_sf, crs = natearth_crs)


If all our data clean and ready, we can start the actual plotting.









Code
font_title <- "Libre Franklin"
font_body <- "Inter"
showtext_auto()

title <- "Largest LGBT Events Worldwide"
subtitle <- "Most recent event per city (top 10), sized by estimated attendence"
caption <- "Source: Wikipedia | #30DayMapChallenge | @anabodevan"

legend_data <- data.frame(
  size = c(1e6, 2e6, 4e6),
  label = c("1M", "2M", "4M")
)







Code
pal <- c(
  "#E40303",  # Red
  "#FF8C00",  # Orange
  "#FFED00",  # Yellow
  "#008026",  # Green
  "#24408E",  # Indigo
  "#732982",  # Violet
  "#FF69B4",  # Pink
  "#00CED1",  # Turquoise
  "#9370DB",  # Medium Purple
  "#FFD700"   # Gold
)








Code
ggplot() +
  # World map first
  geom_sf(data = world_transformed, fill = "black", color = "transparent", linewidth = 0.2) +
  
# Event points with pride gradient
  geom_sf(
    data = events_transformed,
    aes(size = attendance, fill = city_color),
    alpha = 0.9,
    shape = 21,
    color = "white",
    stroke = 1
  ) +
  
  # Discrete colors using pride palette
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = pal,
    labels = paste0(
    events_geo_sf |> arrange(desc(attendance)) |> pull(city),
    " - ",
    round((events_geo_sf |> arrange(desc(attendance)) |> pull(attendance)) / 1e6, 1),
    "M (",
    events_geo_sf |> arrange(desc(attendance)) |> pull(year),
    ")"
  ),
    name = NULL,
    guide = guide_legend(
    override.aes = list(size = 5),
    keywidth = 1,
    keyheight = 1
  )
) +
  
  scale_size_area(max_size = 10, guide = "none") + 
  
  # Natural Earth projection 
  coord_sf(datum = natearth_crs) +
  
  labs(
    title = title,
    subtitle = subtitle, 
    caption = caption
  ) + 
  
  theme_void(base_family = font_body) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(
      size = 40, 
      face = "bold", 
      hjust = 0.5,
      margin = margin(t = 10, b = 5),
      family = font_title
    ),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(
      size = 20, 
      hjust = 0.5,
      margin = margin(b = 15),
      color = "#131212de"
    ),
    plot.caption = element_text(
      size = 12, 
      hjust = 0.5,
      margin = margin(t = 10, b = 5),
      color = "#666666"),

    plot.margin = margin(20, 20, 20, 20),
    plot.background = element_rect(fill = "white", color = NA),
    legend.position = "right",
    legend.text = element_text(size = 16, family = font_body),
    legend.spacing.y = unit(0.4, "cm")
  )

Code

1.2 Set theme


Code
theme_30d <- function() {
  # Set base theme  =============================================
  theme_minimal() +
    # Overwrite base theme defaults ============================================
    theme(
      # Text elements ==========================================================
      plot.title = element_text(
        size = 18,
        face = "bold",
        color = "#333333",
        margin = margin(b = 10)
      ),
      plot.subtitle = element_text(
        size = 14,
        color = "#999999",
        margin = margin(b = 10)
      ),
      plot.caption = element_text(
        size = 13,
        color = "#777777",
        margin = margin(t = 15),
        hjust = 0
      ),
      axis.text = element_text(
        size = 11,
        color = "#333333"
      ),
      plot.title.position = "plot",
      plot.caption.position = "plot",

    # Remove axes & gridlines completely
      axis.text = element_blank(),
      axis.title = element_blank(),
      axis.ticks = element_blank(),
      panel.grid = element_blank(),
    )
}  #### thanks r for the rest of us

Challenge Classic: Map linear features (e.g., roads, rivers, migration paths, flow lines). Explore line thickness, color, and direction to convey information.
Brazil’s railway network has declined since its peak in the 20th century because of a number of reasons, from the crisis in coffee market during the Great Depression to a policy of highway expansion and lobby from car manufacturers in the 1950s. BBC has a pretty cool article about it (in portuguese). Overall, Brazilian railway network lost over 8.000 kilometers since the 20th century.
For Day 2 of the #30DayMapChallenge my idea was to map the decline in Brazil’s railway network.

shp_rail <- sf::st_read(shp_file, quiet = TRUE)

# get brazil and south america shapefiles

shp_latam <- ne_countries(type = "countries", continent = "south america", returnclass = "sf")

shp_latam <- shp_latam %>% 
  st_transform(crs = st_crs(shp_br))

# read kilometer extension
km <- readxl::read_xls("kms.xls")










Code
colnames(km) <- km[3, ]
km <- km[-(1:3), ]
km <- km[-(133:135), ]
rownames(km) <- NULL
colnames(km) <- c("YEAR", "KM")
km$YEAR <- gsub("\\.+", "", km$YEAR) # get the right col names and clean it up 

km$YEAR <- as.integer(km$YEAR)
km$KM <- as.integer(km$KM)

km <- km |> 
  arrange(YEAR) |> 
  mutate(
    delta_km = KM - lag(KM),
    pct_change = 100 * delta_km / lag(KM)
  )

km <- km   |> 
  add_row(YEAR = 2025, KM = 29165) |> 
  arrange(YEAR) |> 
  mutate(
    delta_km = KM - lag(KM),
    pct_change = 100 * delta_km / lag(KM)
  ) # 2025 data from ANTT

      labels = c("Operating", "Under Repair", "Under Study", "Under Study", "Deactivated")
